message_1: A rocket is launched from Earth with an initial velocity of 500 m/s. Its altitude can be modeled by the function h(t) = -0.3t^2 + 500t, where t is the time in seconds after launch. The rocket has a maximum fuel capacity of 10,000 liters and its engine burns fuel at a constant rate of 20 liters per second. What is the maximum altitude the rocket can reach before running out of fuel?
message_2:
First, we need to determine how long the rocket can burn fuel before running out. We can do this by dividing the total fuel capacity by the fuel consumption rate:

Fuel capacity / Fuel consumption rate = Time
10,000 liters / 20 liters per second = 500 seconds

Now that we know the rocket will run out of fuel after 500 seconds, we can plug this value into the altitude function h(t) to find the maximum altitude:

h(t) = -0.3t^2 + 500t
h(500) = -0.3(500)^2 + 500(500)

h(500) = -0.3(250,000) + 250,000
h(500) = -75,000 + 250,000
h(500) = 175,000 meters

So the maximum altitude the rocket can reach before running out of fuel is 175,000 meters.
